bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas and Lydia Cabrera, November 7, 1952

div1.p: Hench expresses his concerns about the naming of the Camp Lazear memorial and the renovation of Building No. 1. He requests that Rojas speak with Nogueira about the project.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas and Lydia Cabrera, November 7, 1952
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
November 7, 1952
Miss Maria Teresa Rojas
Miss Lydia Cabrera
Quinta San Jose
Calle Real
Quemados de Marianao
Havana, Cuba
My dear Tina and Lydia:
div1.p:
I suspect that by now you are back home in Havana. I wonder if you have had
a chance to look over my letters. Have you learned anything? Have there been
any comments in the papers about the impending dedication of Camp Lazear? I
have received no clippings from anybody from Havana for months.

Although I have had frequent correspondence from Doctor Nogueira who assures
me that all is going well and repeatedly reassured me that Reed's Building
No. 1 will not be renamed, I strongly suspect that the place will be called
“Parque Finlay” although he has not actually said so. I am sure that he wants
to do the right thing but his superiors may over-rule him.

May I tell you in strictest confidence that although I have been maintaining
my faith in Doctor Nogueira (I can do no other) I have just sent to Dr. Felipe
Carbonell (the Cuban doctor who has been so interested in this venture) and to
Mrs. R. Hart Phillips (Havana representative of the New York Times whom I have
known for years) a confidential note asking them to give me whatever informa-
tion they can, telling them the background of the affair and asking them to
make discreet inquiries from Doctor Nogueira regarding the plans, if such seem
in order. In your absence and not hearing from you, I felt it necessary to
contact these to other possible agents in Havana.

If you are inclined to do so, perhaps you might telephone Doctor Nogueira, tell
him that on your return from Europe you saw all the activity around Building
No. 1, and that you wondered exactly what the plans were, when the camp was
being dedicated, and so on. That would be a natural inquiry for you to make.

I hope to fly down for the ceremony. I doubt if Mary will come as it will be
a very quick trip.

I have given Doctor Nogueira a list of the various Americans to receive of-
ficial invitations. I don't believe any official invitations have gone out
yet.

I have been considerably distressed by another thing. Doctor Nogueira and I
have frequently talked about trying to preserve, as intact as possible, the
original shell of Building No. 1. I had hoped that a new outer shell would
be built around the original building. About a month ago, without prior
consultation or discussion, he merely wrote me that they were already making
extensive repairs to the building, tearing out part of the old wood. I cabled
and wrote him at once, expressing the hope that they could preserve as much of
the original wood as possible and asked him to save for me (to use later for
souvenirs) as much of the old wood walls as possible. He assured me that he
would, but photographs from him which arrived yesterday show that they removed
Miss Maria Teresa Rojas
Miss Lydia Cabrera
- 2 -
November 7, 1952
practically all of the walls which makes me believe that they will end up
with a replica rather than a restoration. This distresses me greatly but per-
haps it was unavoidable unless they were prepared to take special care and do
a special job.

Tina, I must not ask you to fight my battles and if you feel that you should
not contact Doctor Nogueira, that is quite all right; however if you do see
some clippings in the papers, I should appreciate having them as it would
keep me informed as to how things are going. Doctor Nogueira has invited
enough Americans, including the Surgeon General, etc., so that I am sure
they intend to do the right thing. They also have asked me to speak for
five or ten minutes, presumably at the dedication, which they wouldn't do
unless they were sure that I and my compatriots would be pleased with the
whole affair.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
